posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To recap:

>Last year, Pokemon added support for more games, letting Pokemon freely move between three sets of games as long as they exist in that game.

These games are:
>SwSh
>BDSP
>PLA

The reason this is relevant is because unlike all the games of gen 3 (for example) these games all use completely different data structures. The only reason they can freely move between each other is due to some clever engineering in Pokemon Home.

>Why is this relevant?
Because it means they have the infrastructure to do this with every game going forward.

With the new system they have, you can send the Pikachu you caught in gen 11 back to Sword & Shield, and vice versa. Based on the way they're engineering this solution, it actually seems like it might be MORE work to stray away from this paradigm.

So the question is this, anon
>Do you think this is a reasonable replacement for the old way they did things (all Pokemon in every gen but forward transfers only)?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52953793
Not really. What utility does a Pikachu in gen 11 have over a Pikachu that was caught in gen 8? The only thing I could potentially see given the scenario as of right now is that you could catch a Pokemon in gen 9 with a special mark not obtainable in gen 8 (like the size marks) and back transfer it to get ribbons not available in gen 9, but I see next to no real utility to do this other than collection purposes or Ribbon Masters.
Which also begs the question, why not go all the way and get marks that are unique to Sword/Shield (Curry Mark, Fog Mark, Catch of the Day mark) and transfer forwards anyways? If we're talking purely about tradeoffs, it is not a reasonable replacement. I'm not even a BBNDer or anything of the sort, but if we are framing it in terms of one or the other, I would definitely rather have the other system.
To be honest however, it is cool- they just need to put actual things to do in each gen that would make me want to actually do this. There are 3 unique things in gen 8 you would want to do this for (Restricted Sparring, Path of Solitude, BDSP Battle Tower) for battling and literally one game has contests.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52954069
Also as a final thought to this, but the two games that do not allow back transferring- PoGo and LGPE are the games that would unironically benefit from this the most given the Master Trainer battles or just having your trained Pokemon from your games in PoGo for raids.

Depends on the selection of mons you're including. It could result in cases where fast and frail mons miss out on some key one-shots, and thus get knocked out more easily in return. It also makes bulky pokemon with reliable recovery more valuable, since they'll be taking less damage and healing it off more easily.

For an in-game playthrough though, the differences are more likely to be fairly minimal, so long as you aren't intentionally designing enemy teams around abusing the extra bulk.

>>52939302
I would personally add them as companions/followers that don't take up a party slot. That way you can have their personality and appearance but not need to tinker with balance or figuring out how to make them something the player will want to use. Other anons made valid points that adapting the LGPE partner system isn't a terrible approach either, but I would recommend they are part of a pool you can select from / earn throughout the game.

I would personally implement them as a Pokemon that provides a noticeable buff to your team, similar to badge buffs. That way people who want to use their favorites have even more reason to do so, and others can use specific mons to craft a team that leverages that advantage. A lot of potential depth there with minimal investment, and you don't need to give up letting them be used in battle.

>>52939174
>>52940021
>>52939209
The truth isn't determined democratically. Doesn't matter how many hate hearing this.

The process of running back and forth to the Pokemon Center to heal is dull. It's not gameplay, it's tedium best removed from the experience, or sped up.

You're trading seconds of IRL life for a heal ingame. Would anything fundamentally vital to the core gameplay loop of finding and catching Pokemon and battling trainers be lost if this process was 6x faster? Would it do anything good for that loop if the process took 6x longer?

Would anything really change if there was a Key Item that healed you on the spot after being forced to wait for the time it would take for your player character to run back to the Pokemon Center?
Like a facebook game for wine aunts?
Could be argued that the choice to use a Pokemon center instead of a limited supply of healing items is an interesting choice, but that would be FUCKING WRONG, because enough grinding gives you infinite money.

Ever play Dark Souls?

The only Dark Souls game I've played so far respawns enemies if you run back to heal.
The player is punished for running back to heal. This turns running back to heal into a choice with trade offs.
Is it worth running back to heal, and re-doing this route again? Would you do better this time, know what to watch out for, improve as a player? It also ensures any moment where you take damage puts you closer to death and the need to retry. This adds tension to the combat. Makes you avoid damage. Speeds up the process of dying to restore your health and retry the challenge again, adds tension to that by making you lose something when you die.

No meaningful interesting choices are made when gameplay boils down to "mash A for a bit" or "backtrack to the pokemon center and backtrack back to where I was" and nothing is lost by speeding this process up.

Do you know what's gained when this process is sped up?

Time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If anything, they should make a Pokecenter-based game where healing is the main appeal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52955080
I think you would enjoy Peridot, assuming you're not the dev here.

Gyms are dungeons you can't leave unless you black out or beat the gym leader. You better come prepared with healing items and ethers or else you will have some trouble getting through. Items are more expensive and trainers give less money so you won't be carrying more than 10 or so hyper potions and revives even by the end game. You also can't heal in battle with the gym leader, the game is defaulted to set (but you can change to switch in the options) and the game heavily limits grinding because Pokémon will stop obeying if you train past 5 or so levels above the gym leader.

It's challenging but not unfair and every design choice is deliberate. The actual map design is also very good, free and interconnected.

They did not go whole hog and force all trainers to be rematches if you backed out of the route, but I see your train of thought. posts.com:
https://www.siliconera.com/funny-stories-of-pokemon-english-name-localizations/
>Seth McMahill, Assistant Manager of Product Marketing at Nintendo, has been working exclusively on Pokémon games throughout his career at the company.
>When we spoke with McMahill recently, we asked if he had any interesting or amusing stories to tell from his days localizing the older games. McMahill recalled a couple of instances for us.
>“When you’re naming them, you’re together in a room with a counterpart from NCL (Nintendo Co. Ltd.),” McMahill shared. “We would basically have a thesaurus, a whiteboard on the wall, and would lock ourselves in for days on end, and the days would turn into months.”
>He continued: “The craziest one is… my wife was about to have a baby. So I’m at home, going through baby name books. I’m at work, going through baby name books, along with thesauruses and dictionaries. And after a while, stuff starts to sound weird. So, we had Piplup (Japanese name: Pochama), and the description from Japan was: ‘the sound of a small pebble in the water’. That was what we had to come up with.”
>McMahill recalls: “What we came up with was Piploop, which sounded like ‘poop’.”
>“And we didn’t even think of that,” he says. “No one thought of it. And we were talking to another group, saying we’d finally figured it out, and they went: ‘Poop?’ They said it sounded like poop. And I said, ‘It does not sound like poop! You don’t know what you’re talking about; I’ve been doing this for years!'”
>“And then, finally, after a good night’s rest, I thought: ‘That does sound like poop…’ So, we ended up with Piplup, which was the final name.”

I used to think the same way as you, but I felt like I've better understood what Masuda is going for. Relating to the game from what Masuda says here, the angle that they were going for AZ and Lysandre makes more sense. I don't think it's purely a coiciendence that in Lysandre's final moments, you, your rival, and Shauna basically ask him to make a better world together, and when he doesn't accept, he literally dies. As a contrast, AZ who rejected the value of these things for violence wanders the world aimlessly, but once he makes the effort to try and better understand others (the parade scene which seems out of place), then he is ultimately rewarded with the life of his Floette. I think while the execution of some of its elements and themes can be juvenile or low quality, I think the core concept of what they were going for is incredibly strong from this perspective.

>>52930797
The difference is that cyrus was a sociopath with no empathy while Lysandre was supposed to be (or at least framed as) an empathetic man who sees an issue but choses a method that an empathetic character should usually be opposed to.
Cyrus wanted to reset the world and kill anyone on it because he didnt give a shit, this simplistic outview isn't particularly profound or complex, but its simplicity works. He's not gonna win any awards, but he as a cartoon villain he's fine.
Lysandre wanted to reset the world and kill anyone on it because... he was opposed to their suffering due to ressource shortage. They tried to make him this misguided villain with a good heart, but in the end he just looks retarded.

I agree with you though OP, instead of trying to make a complex plot they should continue to make it simple or silly. Team Skull and Team Star work because their motivations are streamlined: They are misfits who found eachother and are now up to mild mischief.
(Team Stars Admincharacters are also charming enough to make the basic plot fun to follow in my opinion)
Team Rocket is a crimesyndicate who wants to make money, so they make it by unethical means. Team Plasma wants to rule the world, or at least Ghetsis wants to, and tries to do so through manipulation. Team Galactic wants to reset the world because they don't like how emotions make humans illogical.
I like Team Aqua and Magma for nostalgias sake, but truth be told they are equally stupid as Lysandre, choosing a stupid path that conflicts with their motivation to make the world a better place, despite being told by their admin that what they are doing is a bad idea.
I guess Team Yell had the right idea, but let's not kid ourselves they are lame too.

Didn't expect to analyze what I like about evil teams but here I am.

>>52939177
I posted in this thread last week about buying the set of Magical Pokemon Journey volumes in Japanese. They came in today.

One really bizarre thing that people who've seen the raws may or may not know is that the printed volumes literally cut off the text that goes past the designated page borders. Like one panel just a few pages into the first volume has one kanji just cut in half by the top of the page, and the entire last line of dialogue in another panel of the same chapter is cut off along the left side. It's the sloppiest shit I've ever seen in a Japanese manga edition, to the point that I wondered if I got some weird bootlegs and that's the reason they were so cheap. But nope, looking up the raws shows the same problem exists in the scans from, what, a decade or two ago, so this is all Flower Comic's fault I guess.

(check out the panel on the bottom left of the left page-- you can juuuust see a portion of the last line of dialogue in the speech bubble that's cut off, and in my physical copy it's even more visible than in this old scan because you can make out just a bit more of it)

The volumes are also weirdly... wide or something compared to a standard manga volume and the pages are really white/thick, like they're made of a different kind of paper than usual.

>Ace
Froslass

Ice/Ghost, Fluttermane can be interchangeable with Mismagius

>Inside Gym theme
https://youtu.be/Ms_WPizqN9o with a few traditional japanese notes

https://youtu.be/V2jRaufDfQQ

>Gym Aesthetic
An old abandonned traditional japanese manor on top of a snowy mountain. The manor itself is half-destroyed in some parts and the snow can come in.
The climb to the gym is hindered by a huge blizzard, with ice types roaming, and also ghost types at night.
It is difficult to find your way in the storm, but you will ocasionally see fom afar a beautiful woman dressed entirely in a white yukata with white hair and pale skin that doesn't seem entirely human, seemingly show you the way to the top.
Be careful however as she is quite mischevious and will sometimes bring you in obvious traps or misdirections that will make you lose your way in deep snow that make it difficult to walk.
Once you find the gym, she will be there more often but will completely lead you astray and make you lose yourself in rooms and encounter climbers or posessed spiritualists that will challenge you in battle. The trick to find the right way is not to trust her anymore at that point.
The gym leader is a beautiful woman not unlike the one that guided you through the snow, but with jet-black long hair going to her waist, and normal skin. The two share a strange ressemblance as if they were related.

The battle opens with Snow Warning Ninetales (Or it will hail/snow in the gym leader room by default) and ends with Snow Cloak Froslass. The ghosts have stuff like will-o-wisps (cold can "burn") and destiny bond.
Naturally all the special ice types will use Blizzard and not Ice Beam as their main ice STAB

Badge ideas:
A ghostly ice-blue flame
A white yukata sash
A white traditional japanese fan with purple complexions

The gym will mysteriously be absent during the day, and there will only be a vast empty area with some few wooden ruins standing in its place...

posts.com:
>ace
H. Zoroark
>battle theme
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q6FHO70J2u8
>gym aesthetic
A nice cottage whose interior walls are all wood, with lots of comfy sofas completely covered with big, puffy pillows all overs, nice soft rugs, beds with the softest bedding, basically a place where my Pokemon and backup trainers could lounge all day. It would be decorated with warm Christmas hanging from the ceiling or around the various balconies, with candles lit up to truly seal that comfy atmosphere. The leader's Pokemon are all quite high maintenance with their hair's health and overall appearance, that's why they spend most of the day sitting lazily like divas, so as to not mess up their looks.

The challenge would involve all of the candles being automatically put off and the challenger having to go all around the cottage trying to light them up before the time limit, but sometimes hallways or balconies will be blocked off by trainers who will either battle or give a quick quiz question before letting them through.

Only chose this character because of the hair, the gym leader would actually be a woman with long, white hair on a ponytail, wearing comfortable sleeping clothes (loose tank top and pants, with a transparent lace pajama coat on top), whom upon meeting is currently brushing her Zoroark. Upon seeing you she will pretend to be annoyed that you're interrupting her relax time and making her stand up (she's very lazy), but in reality she's really excited and was eagerly waiting for a challenger. By clapping her hands, she recalls all of her Pokemon into her room, where they'll promptly go back into their balls and the battle will begin.

The badge would be a white pillow that doubles as a cloud, with those string things that pillows have on the corners being lilac.

Oh I was just going for comfy vibes in general, a place to be really laid-back, hence the setting being kinda like picrel, everyone wearing comfy clothes/pajamas, the Pokemon just chilling around over the cushy pillows (since the mons have long hair I figured they'd just lay around, letting it all hang freely so as to not get tangled), the warm candles and lights, etc. (also maybe these kind of lights are called something else, but I associate these string like lights with Xmas ones, so maybe that caused the confusion? At first glance it appears to be a simple cave but the first opening area has a series of caverns crawling with researchers. The "challenge" is simple, you must pay close attention to which scientist are actually doing their job and which ones are complaining(Complaints range from the state of the gym and the temperature to how they just outright dislike being forced to be gym trainers). The ones complaining will give you not so subtle hints that point you in the direction of the cavern you should go down. As you progress deeper into the caves temperature will steadily drop, the walls turning to ice until you find the gym leader in a room ice surrounded by ice furniture and 2 sculptures.
You'll learn he's a living relic from the past that was defrosted. Due to his knowledge he would've been taken in but his battle prowls made it rather difficult. So instead a deal was struck, if he was supplied with food and left alone with his family(the 2 ice sculptures) he would in turn answer any questions the researchers had about the past and become a gym leader.

>>52954031
Yep, I'll probably work on a guide or something soon.

But for now; basically first we decide on the pokemon, you want to be violet to maximize but anything works.

Once we get that set, we follow this
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1Krmy76O7u4ZHG-QySfmNa-85UHwDnvJIldfOhr-cxRs/htmlview#

We save before we union circle.
We do the circle and fly to the area zero gate.
Depending on what we hunt, we either do one sandwich at once or a different sandwich for each.

We split, the more ground we cover more spawns we get = higher odds of shinies, we've gotten up to 4 in a single sandwich run.

Here's the basic:

>1) Know where it can spawn, go to that area, during union circle only 5 pokemon can spawn near you.
>2) Move around, move back and forth, move between two locations, etc, you just need to keep spawning them while also checking each one of them

>3) If you find a shiny, CARE, DO NOT ENGAGE IT, SAVE AND AVOID FIGHTING IT

>4) Announce what you found and where in the thread, wait for confirmation on whos catching it, when to restart, etc

>But why wouldn't I just catch it?

On union circle the player that finds the shiny, aka, the cartridge that generates it, can save in front and once they restart the shiny will be there since it originated for them.
This means that up to two players can catch the same shiny, the player that finds it after he restarts and one other person.

Example: I find a shiny Scream Tail, I can save in front, say in thread "shiny scream tail in front of lab 4, already saved and you're free to engage" so you can just find it and catch it, after that we ideally keep running the rest of the sandwich and if nothing shows up, I restart


Couple things to know;
>If it aggros DON'T RUN, union circle mons despawn if you run away
>You're likely to get other shiny mons on the way, so for these and the paradox bring a pokemon that can make catching them easier like a Breloom or Gallade.

Anyone else can join for the record, 4 max.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Self-Destruct and Explosion should have the same base power but Explosion should be a special fire-type move. They should both keep the defensive stat reducing stealth effect from before the nerf.

“Never miss” moves like Swift should still hit its target during moves like Fly and Dig like they did in Gen 1. It’s less about making sense and more about buffing underused moves for balance in a way that keeps the spirit of the move.

Tackle should have 35 base power with 95 accuracy like it originally had. It’s supposed to be a basic but mediocre move that weak Pokémon start out with. You’re supposed to be happy to get rid of it with something better. Buffing it to 50 is dumb and makes Nuzlocking Gen 5 a pain in the ass.

Bug should be super effective against poison-type like it was in Gen 1. Less about making sense and more about balance since bug-type is so fucking shit.
>make fairy-type
>give them resistance to bug just to make sure bug-type will always be shit
JUST

Moves like Sonic Boom and Dragon Rage should just do damage equal to the user’s move like Seismic Toss and Nightshade. Having a move only do 20 or 40 damage is really worthless outside of the first hour or two in the game. They’re also both equally worthless in competitive regardless of the generation, if that counts for anything.

Rock Smash should drop defense 100% of the time. The move is weak as shit and buffing it wouldn’t make any impact in competitive play. As it stands, the move is a shitty version of Power-Up Punch. And yeah, not everything should be balanced for competitive but shit like Constrict (10 base power?????) should at least work 100% of the time.
>Gen 1: lowers speed; 33% chance
>Gen 2-7: lowers speed; 10% chance
>Gen 8+: the move does not exist
LMAO. I get that some moves are meant to be weak to give them a niche but at least DON’T FUCKING NERF THEIR EFFECT WHEN THEY’RE ALREADY A WORTHLESS MOVE

>Eevee
They're only a pain in the ass if you don't play Crystal, if you have Crystal you can delete all phone numbers but the one you need then go to your mom and change to daylight savings time over and over until you get the call.
I chose Umbreon in my current nuzlocke of crystal (I'm in Kanto) and it has been useful but a bit underwhelming. Just can't fucking die though, so I guess I can't ask for more. Notable thing about Umbreon is eevee gets bite at level 30, there's your STAB. Also you get confuse ray as Umbreon at 30 so evolving specifically at level 30 is nice.
Espeon doesn't get psybeam until 36 which kinda sucks but you will get bite (special) and have return until 36 which is totally fine as long as you aren't going to rely on it before Clair too much.
If I had to choose again I might go for Espeon, so much stronger.
>Abra
Yeah its so boring. Gengar is more based because it does the same thing eventually but you have to work towards it and gastly/haunter are actually really good troll pokemon
>Sandshrew
I used it in this run until I caught Rhydon which purely outclasses it in every way even down to a better typing for most matchups. It was pretty good, I used it to beat Whitney. Its very physically bulky for early and midgame and ground type is very useful to have. All you really need on him is headbutt and dig and then replace headbutt with return/strength.
There is no rock slide tm, no. It sucks but he doesn't strictly need it.
>Dratini
Not fucking worth it he's gonna suck dick until level 30 when you get dragonair, by then your options are water coverage, pansy ass weak dragon move and normal coverage. He won't be dragonite by the elite four. He's weak to Clair's mons. Its pretty shit.

For Goldenrod encounters Abra is obviously best, but Eevee is runner up. Dratini might be interesting if you can actually keep him alive if this is a nuzlocke, just use him if you really wanna try it out.

There's not much to comment on between Bugsy and Whitney. I failed to catch an owl in National Park, something I'm sure won't bite me in the ass later I guess.
As for Whitney, I came up with a plan that should work nicely.
Lead with Togetic, Charm Clefairy to -6 Attack just to be safe, switch to Skiploom to Paralyze it, then to Dunsparce (Holding Zoom Lens), set up Defense Curls for safety and Rollout till the cow comes home.
Now, as you can see, this is a perfectly foolproof plan and nothing could possibly go wrong.
So I do all the set-up, switch to Dunsparce...
>Clefairy uses Self-Destruct
Oh. Well, because of the Charms, it doesn't really do damage, but now I didn't get my setup.
What I should've done here is switch out and Paralyze the thing immediately instead of trying to Headbutt to victory, but alas, I did not.
After Dunsparce and Geodude reached a low enough HP threshold, I gave in and turned to Skiploom to Paralyze it, but neither of them (Nor Togetic) can really switch in, and despite my best attempts, nothing else I had could bring the attractive, lactating bovine down.
A sack was unavoidable, but I probably should've let Paras take that particular L, as it's been dead weight all this time, but instead that fell on Skiploom.
After this, Dunsparce was able to come in and finish the job, thanks to the Rock Smashing prep work to tenderize the walking beef.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52952302
It should be an interesting run. I don't know the full extent of changes since I haven't played Crystal, but I have some notes from my research for the franchise challenge:
>early Growlithe in route 36
>Phanpy availabe on that route northeast of Violet Town
>Teddiursa available in Dark Cave
>free odd egg from the day care (can be Pichu, Igglybuff, Cleffa, Tyrogue, Smoochum, Elekid or Magby)
>free Eevee in Goldenrod
>Cubone available in Game Corner
>Move Tutor in Goldenrod ($4000 for Flamethrower, Thunderbolt and Ice Beam)
>Snubbull available in route 34 (no swarm necessary)
>Sneasel available in Ice Cave
>Marill available in route 42 (no swarm necessary)

I don't know about how viable all of those choices are, but Move Tutor is definitely a gain and you can't really say no to a free mon from Odd Egg
Cubone probably just alright without Thick Club (only available in Johto), Azumarill doesn't seem too great considering other Water options available (though it has access to RestTalk), Teddiursa is really good with STAB Return and access to all elemental punches

There are probably more relevant changes but this is all I've got

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52952616
mud slap 20BP x2 (SE) = 40BP on geodude
gust 40BP x1.5 (STAB) x0.5 (NVE) = 30BP on geodude
effectively it's only dealing 25% more damage than its resisted gust. in gen 4 it's more of a problem because mud slap is special and geodude/onix have poor special defense. the accuracy drop is annoying too, but it's far from broken. it's good game design because it teaches you that pokemon can have coverage moves that help them deal with their weaknesses.

This thread is for Hacks and/or Clones. Come in and get free stuff!

>>52951942
Toedscool/Toedscruel couldn't be regional forms because the leap from "fully aquatic creature with gills" to "fully terrestrial creature with lungs" would be too big.
Regional forms are simply an existing mon adapting to a new (but not inhospitable) environment, while convergents are entirely new mons that are using an existing mon's advantageous features in an environment that would be inhospitable to the existing mon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a few games now, GF has been buffing some of the lamer abilities. Like giving a lot of the crappy Gen 3 ones that just blocked Confusion/Attrraction or whatever the additional ability to block Intimidate, as an example. So what other ones would you tweak?

>Magma Armor
Becomes more like a defensive Water Bubble. Still blocks Freeze but also heavily reduces damage from Water and Ice moves (taking them to 0.25x damage, treating them as a double resist)
Why?: Only two lines get it and both are kind of garbage right now. This gives them an opportunity to mitigate a 4x weakness by cutting it by a quarter, making it a neutral hit, and then making Ice attacks deal 1/8 damage, as they naturally resist already. It doesn't radically change Magcargo into a good Pokémon, but it does have more chances to do something. Camerupt may benefit a lot more actually becoming more viable on different types of teams as a "Snow" counter or a good utility mon on Sun and Sand teams

>Corrosion
Still let's you poison Poison and Steel types, but now also works like Scrappy to let you ingore Steel's immunity to Poison moves altogether
Why?: It's kind of weird it doesn't work like this already. The Salazzle line doesn't really need this buff, but a special attacking Glimmora (rather than a suicide lead) becomes a lot more viable.

>Mycelium Might
Additionally lets your spore and powder moves hit Grass types
Why?: Another one that should probably just work like this anyway. Currently this ability is kind of garbage since it forces you to go last and the most frequent move you would be using, Spore, is already going to hit 90% of the things you're using it on. Might as well let it hit Grass types too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
Any ability that provides immunity to a status should now also provide bonus type 'resists', to match with purifying salt.
Magma armor reducing damage from Ice/Water movies is a good example. But you could also do a similar thing with Oblivious and Fairy moves, or Insomnia/Vital Spirit to shrug off psychic attacks. Immunity, Limber, and Water Veil helping against Poison, Electric, and Fire would also be a given.

I don't know if it'd make any mons with those abilities too crazy, since most of those with them have better options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
>Hyper Cutter
Prevents Attack lowering AND now buffs power of "claw" moves
Why?: Blocking Intimidate is kind of neat but all the Pokémon with this ability aren't very viable, which is a shame. Let's make it like Sharpness and recategorize a bunch of moves as "claw" moves. The actual description of this ability currently mentions you get the ability because you have a powerful pincer/claw. So some moves would have crossover with Sharpness, like X-Scissor, but there would also be uniquely claw moves like Crabhammer, Vice Grip and Crush Claw. Does this help a lot of Pokémon become more viable? Probably not. But I just really want to see Kingler and Mawile not be shit again.

>Big Pecks
Prevents Defense lowering AND now buffs the power of wind and wing moves (because you're using your big pectoral muscles to flap those wings of yours that make the wind, obv)
Why?: A lot of Pokémon have this ability circa Generation 5 and 6, then they pulled way the fuck back and I think only one new Pokémon has it since. It would be neat for the bird Pokémon who have this to actually get some benefit from it rather than just an immunity to defense dropping that doesn't really matter for them because they're not very defensive. Getting a buff to wind and wing moves would be nice. And the only reason I included wing moves is because they're so few why the fuck not?

The abilities that don't do anything in battle should all be given an actual purpose.

>Illuminate
Lowers the evasion of all Pokemon on the field by one stage. This goes hand in hand with the out-of-battle effect of making Pokemon easier to find by illuminating the area.
You now want to use Illuminate Starmie with Hydro Pump, Thunder and Blizzard.

The Pokemon can always switch out in trainer battles regardless of trapping abilities or moves. It baffles me how this is not already the case.

>Ball Fetch

>Honey Gather
If the Pokemon is holding Honey, it will consume it at 25% health or less, restoring 50% of its max HP. At the end of every turn there is a 50% of the consumed Honey being replaced by a new one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Stall
Additional effect where this Pokemon holds off taking damage during the turn until it has finished attacking. This way it's not a complete dud. You're guaranteed to get something off before going down. The ability would activate when it gets hit and then the HP bar doesn't drop until after it moves. It could still take passive damage though, I guess

>Forewarn
Pokémon now still warns you about the strongest move of the adjacent opponent, instead of a random opponent in a double battle. The Pokemon is now then also guaranteed to avoid all damage the first turn right after switching in. This will help Pokémon like Jynx, Hypno and Musharna guarantee they can get off that boost or status move the first turn.

>Anticipation
The Pokémon still shudders if the opponent has a SE move or OHKO move, but now the ability activates every time either the user switches is in or an opponent does. Every time it shudders, it also gains a +1 Speed boost sorta like Rattled. Every one of the Pokémon that gets this ability has something else it would rather run, but it may have a niche use for some things. For example, DDing Whiscash can come in and guarantee it will be fast enough to get off the DD. Or something like Toxicroak, which has somewhat decent coverage, can be sort of a twisted revenge killer that doesn't have to rely on Sucker Punch to "out speed" a Psychic or Flying type.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52929340
gonna give some solid buffs to some real stinkers

>Heavy Metal
On top of doubling weight, also halves damage from Fighting-type moves.
Why?: Pretty obviously, a thicker, heavier metal is a lot harder to break with your bare hands than something lighter.

>Light Metal
On top of halving weight, also halves damage from Ground-type moves.
Why?: This one's technically a bit of a stretch, as ironically weaker earthquakes typically affect smaller buildings more than larger buildings, while larger buildings are more likely to be damaged by severe earthquakes.
But "light" metal could also be interpreted as being a more flexible material, which would in fact be able to better absorb shockwaves than something more rigid.

>Keen Eye
Boosts accuracy upon entering battle.
Why?: Because it makes more sense for something with strong eyes to have a greater accuracy advantage than to simply be better at coping with sand getting flung into its eyes.

>Hyper Cutter, Big Pecks
Now also prevents the user from lowering their Attack/Defense respectively
Why?: They're already direct downgrades from something like Clear Body, might as well give it SOME kind of niche given that they're almost always paired with far better abilities anyways

>Anticipation
Raises speed if the foe has a super effective move.
Why?: Because Anticipation is garbage and learning whether your opponent has a coverage move against you is not worth sacrificing a real ability (which given its almost always paired with a far better ability, is usually the case)

I think that abilities were first created because they wanted to have a way to make Pokémon do things like levitate or change forms w weather but didn't know how to do it. From their abilities sort of evolved but they didn't want them to be anything overbearing, so we got stuff like hyper cutter. In comes generation 5 and they try to tweak the meta in a lot of ways, one of them was coming up with much better abilities. By 6 and 7 we now have a significant jump in abilities that are tailor-made for specific Pokémon and they wouldn't function without them. And then Generations 8 and 9 continue this trend, while also going back and tweaking older abilities.

>TLDR abilities were originally meant to be kind of useless, but their tune changed as time went on and now they pretty much define the Pokémon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52952220
Not alone. Dark being immune to Prankster seems so tacked on and doesn't even make sense in a lot of cases. The argument I think they are making is that because you are a dirty fighter you can't be one upped, so you block Prankster boosted attacks. But if you think about it too hard, it doesn't make sense because Pokémon with Prankster should be be able to "outsmart" a Dark type based on their lore for being tricksters. And how exactly is just being a Dark type magically making you immune to being pranked? You're telling me some fat spiky bastard like Overqwil is too clever to have a Whimsicot Tailwind in its face? Electric being immune to Paralysis bugs me too because paralysis wasn't always necessarily an Electric-tied status. You could cause it via other moves, whereas Freeze and Burn were only caused by moves of that type (outside Tri-Attack). It just makes no sense to me that because it's an Electric type of Pikachu can't be paralyzed by a Snorlax using Body Slam. I know there are a lot of things that don't 100% make sense, but that's something I feel should follow logic. And even if you can make the argument that Electric types are meant to be fast and have "twitchy" muscles so they can't be paralyzed... That rationale doesn't really hold up for more than a few Electric types actually. The only way it makes sense is saying that paralysis was always an electric elemental status effect and they could just absorb it, but again that wasn't always the case and I think it makes more sense to just let them be paralyzed by moves that aren't electric or have them shake off paralysis faster than normal.

>>52929340
Back on topic

>Plus/Minus
Now buff SpDef on Electric Terrain, with or without a partner that has the ability. Also stacks with the old effect, so now you can send in say Plusle and Minun on Electric Terrain to get both of them +1/+1 in SpAtt/SpDef. Or just send in Ampharos on Electric Terrain for that sweet free +1 SpDef, use Cotton Guard, and then laugh as you don't fucking die while throwing out boosted Discharges next to your Ground-type/Volt Absorb mon.

>Normalize
Now also treats incoming moves as Normal-type moves, but only if they target this Pokemon. Yeah, that's still kinda shit especially because only Delcatty has this move. But now Delcatty is not only throwing out boosted Normal everything but they're also not taking SE damage from Fighting attacks (and I guess taking neutral from Ghost, but whatever). This would be more interesting if you Skill Swapped it onto something else that would appreciate being completely neutral with everything and doesn't mind losing an ability as the tradeoff, like a defensive Psychic or Ice type that wants to be able to hit things with status moves that normally get absorbed/avoided.

>Symbiosis
Adds an additional effect where this Pokemon also shares healing with its ally. Whenever this Pokemon uses a healing move (NOT item), 10% of the HP it recovers is cut and shared with its ally.

>Lingering Aroma
Reworked to not just be a Mummy clone. When a Pokemon makes contact with you, they pick up a "lingering aroma" that works as a passive status which goes away upon switching out or being KO'd (making this more like Cursed Body, but it always activates). This Pokemon now has a "lingering aroma" which is a passive status that works like Odor Sleuth. The Pokemon with this passive status now has their Evasion changes ignored by all other Pokemon AND can be hit by Fighting and Normal moves if they're a Ghost type. It goes away after 3 turns if it isn't reactivated

posts.com: Noob here, what does Hatterene "moving" to OU mean? Was it banned in UU? But doesn't it have reasonable counters in UU?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52945643
It just means that it got enough usage in OU to become OU. Smogon is a usage based tiering system so the more a Pokemon is used, the higher tier it is. Conversely, the less it's used, the lower tiered it is. Once every 3 months (or month early on), a Pokemon's usage stats are pulled and looked at, and depending on if it hits a certain usage threshold, it can either remain in a tier or drop to a lower one

Sometimes, Pokemon in lower tiers get enough usage in higher tiers to "rise", like Hatterene

>>52943814
> Can you use it to transfer Pokémon from older gens to Home?

Yes. Assuming you know nothing about it; bank was the precursor to Pokemon Home and was used to move from gen 5->6->7 and then up into Home when they changed to that system instead.
When the e-shop closes in March, you won't be able to download it onto a 3DS system anymore. They said they're making Bank free at that point though and no longer need a subscription so anyone that does have it can freely move all their pokemon into Home.

Presumably Bank will shut down at some point in the future, but they haven't said when.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52954599
>Apparently, it matters not that I have Sparkling Electric Power lvl 3 and Encounter lvl 3 if I don't specifically use spicy and salty herba mystica, meaning I encounter any and all types of Pokemon regardless of what I cook.
The reason you're encountering all types of Pokemon is because of how the spawns work. Basically, each section of the map has different spawn tables, and if a section doesn't have any Pokemon in their spawn table of your sandwich type, then they'll just spawn whatever. The rocky areas are right next to a plains section in Area Zero, and because these plains sections don't have any Electric types in their table, they'll just spawn random mons. It has nothing to do with what Herba you use to make your sandwich, it's just how the game generates spawns

>>52951333
Sheer Force is busted in a vacuum but in practice it falls short because it's mostly on physical attackers and most physical moves don't get applicable bonuses. So you have physical Pokémon like Conkeldurr, Braviary, Druddigon who don't really make use of it and others like Nidoking who need to go special despite being physically oriented statwise. Even some like Tauros or Rampardos who need to go mixed despite a pathetic special attacking stat to bring out its full potential and have essential coverage like Earthquake left unboosted.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>and i refuse to belive that nidoking and nidoqueen can’t have biological kids together
With how Pokemon stages work (see visibly elderly Treecko), the appropriate comparison seems to be along the lines of how women in the military can end up going sterile from the stress mixed with how men can remain nominally fertile their entire life. This goes back to one of those Japan-only Game Freak published volumes containing lore, like the Pocket Monsters' ability to go in your pocket being a leveraged innate ability.

Or in other words, the Nidoran lines run on Short Frail Queens To Protecc, Nidorina being a mix of Tomboy Christmas Cake and Grandmama Bear, while Nidoqueen is a steroid-fried amazoness. A Nidoking/Nidoqueen couple in the wild generally HAD children, years ago, before the latter's first evolution, and at this point most likely have grandchildren depending on Moon Stone availability.

>>52944505
I've only got 3 units at 150 (Adler, H.Caitlyn and Ghetsis) and that was only because I couldn't clear the SS Hilbert extreme battle without doing so. 140 has so far been enough for everything in MM.
In terms of leeway, you can get a couple of teams that can just off-type whatever you need them to so they can be thought of as 'get out of jail free' cards. I also have a toxistall team with SS Leaf, The Iris Formerly Known as Champion, and a tank that heals on sync (I now have H.Caitlyn but Sawyer worked totally fine before her).
The most important thing is having busted support units since they don't care about typing. After that you want to look into having powerful strikers in different types.
Lastly, you should be smart about what handicaps you put on. You can make things way harder on yourself if you do suboptimal choices.

skipped on gen 4 because I got sick of pokemon by that point, so I never even knew this kid was retconned into being giovanni's son until I decided to try SS for the first time in early 2021 and then did a little digging afterward. going to rant a bit because shit's been bugging me for a while

first of all, like what's already been mentioned, silver ends up acting a lot like the thing he claims to hate: he steals, he accosts the player, and he speaks down to everyone he perceives as weak. I presume he's has only ever lived around team rocket his whole life, so it's only natural that he would behave in this way because it's likely all he knows. likewise, he should also know that people working together to achieve a common goal is how an organization works, thus making it kind of weird that he'd even be questioning it. in fact I think giovanni himself tells silver this in the celebi event. team rocket are weaklings, yes, but whether they're carrying out their plots as a group or as individuals is kind of irrelevant. they exist solely as fodder to keep the law off giovanni's scent and to protect his interests. that's literally how underground crime rings are supposed to function. if the law finds giovanni, then silver ends up without his father, and team rocket likely crumbles regardless. having tons of disposable goons is not only essential in keeping the business alive, it's NECESSARY. again, silver should know this. HOWEVER, if silver wanted to make a point about how his father is a weakling and a coward for hiding in the shadows while his grunts did all the actual work, then by all means. if he held resentment towards his father for abandoning him after losing some pokemon battles to some random ass kid, once again, he would have been 100% justified in feeling this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
(cont.)
the only problem with this is that giovanni himself admits his own weaknesses and wants to come back stronger himself so that he can be the leader he thinks team rocket properly deserves. this is the part that fucks it all up for me and where my main gripes begin. even giovanni is aware of his own faults and is willing to change to erase them. this is supposed to be an admirable trait, but silver throws a tantrum over it. he should have understood that it was necessary for the good of team rocket, and that he ought to have been waiting for his father's triumphant return to see if the man lived up to the potential he claimed he would. but that's not what ended up happening. instead we get this weird confused mess where gamefreak tried to force pre established characters into new molds while still trying to keep a lot of the original details. shit starts falling apart and stops making sense real quick. maybe someone who knows pokemon lore better can help me to better understand this shit, but I do think gf really fucking dropped the ball on what could have been an infinitely more interesting dynamic between these two characters.

>tl;dr
gamefreak fucked up characterization and I don't like it

>reminder that serperior is a plant before it is a snake, that it photosynthesizes for nutrition instead of eating...
First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
Serperior's dex entries never state that it solely relies on photosynthesis. It would be pretty strange if it did, considering that it's been depicted eating stuff as I mentioned earlier.
>and that unlike actual predator pokemon it uses "foe" instead of prey"

Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. Either way the idea of steel types being " recently discovered" doesn't work if you allow for the type chart to be something that exists within canon rather than a game extraction, because then the nature of reality somehow changes as pokemon researchers discover things. >>52945416
My Onix and Steelix changes.

Onix
>Rock/Dragon
>Rock Head/Sturdy/Sheer Force
>70/95/140/50/55/90 (500)
>Twister (Dragon Rage before it was cut), Dragon Tail, and Dragon Rush added to level-up
>Head Smash and Scale Shot as Egg moves
In Gen 1 Onix would now be found later in the game, and Rhyhorn replaces it in Brock’s gym battle. However, it is still his true ace. Lance would use one now too, and Chuck’s Onix are replaced with one Golem and Primeape.

Onix can now be a bit of a menace, with its main weakness being its paultry special Defence that can be patched up in Sand.

Steelix
>Steel/Dragon
>Rock Head/Jagged (Spikes Debris)/Sheer Force
>90/105/170/40/65/30 (500)
>All of Onix’s movepool additions, Wild Charge, plus two new non-exclusive moves
>Shrapnel Blast, a Steel-type Flare Blitz that can Flinch. Benefits Rock Head and Sheer Force.
>Rebuild, a Normal-type recovery move. The user restores 33% of its health. If there are any entry hazards, the user clears the FIRST APPLIED hazard and heals 50% instead. Hazards are absorbed in the order they are applied. I don’t know if I’d have it only take on stack of (T) Spikes at a time or not.
In Gen 2 and 4, Jasmine would likely keep Steelix as her ace. It wouldn’t have access to its most powerful tools at that level or even in that Gen, so it’s just a fat bastard at that point in the game. Lance would replace one of his Dragonite with one, and the other with Kingdra, to show he’s such a Chad with Dragons he can use the GL’s aces (like Cynthia using Roserade and Lucario).

This is technically a BST nerf for Steelix, and I’m worried I’ve made it less unique for the sake of being more splashable. Like its fellow Metal Coat evo Scizor, it’d keep its base stats and offer more of a defensive playstyle to its prevo, whilst allowing its prevo to go defensive itself with Eviolite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52951016
I think the issue arises because the series doesn't present Pokémon as monsters despite their fantastical nature. Monsters are often associated with aggressiveness, as scary and at times the unknown.

We know from early guidebooks that they didn't want 3rd parties referring to Pokémon as monsters as early as 1998. This is in contrast to series like Digimon where they proudly wear the monster label, and it also helps that Digimon are otherworldy digital creatures. It’s also telling when Pokémon designers talk about ecosystems, or The Pokémon Company explicitly telling others that Pokémon *replace* real animals in-universe with zero mentions of monsters, indeed in that same section TPC tells others not to refer to Pokémon as monsters. Likewise we know thanks to Takeshi Shudo that from the start the anime decided to depict Pokemon and human relationships as the relationship between animals and humans in the real world. Pokémon are usually not portrayed as aggressive nor scary and they're not otherworldly or bizarre, in-universe, creatures, they're very much attached to the natural and the natural world. And more importantly is that the series itself seems to reject the monster label even in the games.

Given these circumstances it shouldn't really surprise us when others don't think of Pokémon as monsters when the series itself doesnt and makes a concentrated effort to separate Pokémon from that label.

>Ash catches Ho-oh
>He turns to Pikachu, "Looks like our journey is finally over huh?"
>A slow clapping is heard from the thicket
>"Well done Ash. Or should I call you, Grand Champion?"
>A figure emerges through the dense fog
>Ash is shocked, "T-Tobias?"
>Tobias smiles, "I'm happy to hear you remember me."
>Ash raises an eyebrow and inquires, "Why are you here?"
>Tobias readies a Pokéball, "Isn't it obvious?"
>Battle start!
>Comes down to Ho-oh and Darkrai
>6-5 Tobias wins
>Ash falls to the ground exhausted, "Guess I'm no longer Grand Champion huh?"
>Tobias extends his hand to help him up, "Nonsense, it was a wonderful battle. Besides, your Pokémon were tired from their previous fight were they not?"
>Ash thinks to himself, "Wait, is he saying I would've won?"
>Ash takes his hand up and asks, "You're not just here to battle are you?"
>Tobias smirks, "As much as I enjoyed our battle, you are correct."
>Ash takes a more serious tone, "Then why?"
>Tobias, "To offer you a position"
>Ash raises an eyebrow, "A position in what?"
>Tobias turns around and begins walking away.
>Ash follows, "Where are we going."
>Tobias, "A place not even those at the height of Pokémon League Champion know about. Come, you'll see."
>They walk together.

"Whiteness" is an unknown concept in the ancient world. "Whiteness" is a modern construct born out of colonialism, slavery and the 19th century. So there's no such thing as whiteness in the past. When the Spartan king Agesilaos II was campaigning in Asia Minor he had his Persian prisoners stripped naked to show his men their pale bodies as a means to show how weak they were, earlier his army almost melted away in fear at the sight of the Persian army which still instilled fear unto their enemies.

What you are asking is imposing a modern construct unto the past which doesn't work. Instead of race you find beliefs of climate change the way people look and their culture. The Greeks of the mainland viewed the Ionian Greeks and those living in the Near East with the same orientalists lense they viewed other people of the Near East like the Persians and Egyptians. posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>52911327
>What kind of cliffhanger does it end on?
It isn't a cliffhanger per se, but it's only the completion of the first story arc of an originally intended three, so there's a lot of stuff that's clearly setup for later resolution that's left open-ended. (It was supposed to be a graphic novel kind of thing but the original character designer and artist dipped about a dozen pages into the first chapter and the author was nine chapters deep, so finishing the first arc felt like the best compromise between not throwing all the work away and not committing to more than the extant work required.)

The problem/reason for that is that the author is a nerd and actually wrote about a dozen things and they're all set in the same continuity, so even ignoring the bits that were for the intended latter two parts, there's also a lot that references other stuff, including stuff that wasn't yet written when it came out.

All that aside, it's a couple dozen chapters of slice-of-life that takes an objective look at the gardevoir-waifu cliche, starter pokemon loyalty issues, where pokemon fit into a human family structure, the innately speculative fiction aspects of things like parallel worlds and transient land masses (as are canon in Pokemon but of a different sort here), the pressures of organized competition, latent psychic emanations, ghosts with attitude, adverse possession law, wildlife management, identity theft, and treatments for acute hypothermia.

But mostly people click on it because "Gardevoir" is in the tags.

posts.name: cge0361

>>52910812
It may no longer be an issue but AO3 used to be notorious for a long sign-up queue. Apply well before you want to post there.

>zwcsp

>The closest was all the way in Sunnyville on the other side of the region. And that was a trip his parents weren’t willing to make.
Are you intending to imply that one must have a Professor-assigned starter to participate in League? Canon has people with pokemon from any origin; the Hero's Journey of Red, Ash, etc. justifies having a pokemon with viable BST.

I feel like this infodump should've been the entirety of Chapter 1 after the funeral scene cold open. As a bulky flashback, you could show rather than tell Travis's efforts to acquire a starter, and time-skip as needed to need only portray "the good stuff." Like, one scene of him trying to get a trip to Sunnyville, another where he's doing yard work to earn money to mail-order some pokeballs and then fails to catch anything with the one/few he gets, and so on. Another where he tries to borrow one and gets told plainly that his acquaintances won't entrust him with the care of their pokemon for several reasons giving him reason to introspect—that could be where he suspends the idea and it lingers and gnaws at him in the background till the expiration of Arcanine.

Instead we're spending a lot of time trying to sell the premise when either the reader is already willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of making acquisition of a starter a momentous (and hitherto belated) event in Travis's life, or it points out the contrivance and makes it more awkward.

The rest of the chapter works well enough, although maybe something more interesting could be done to get them together without it being "that simple." Travis could've lost his keys or phone and had to go back maybe, or leave the encounter a bust but later (after acquiring a starter) Travis goes up the mountain again to grind some levels and encounters it again, and then tries to add it to the roster.

>>52912683
> I really wanted to get things off the ground
The lack of immediate relevance of Travis's backstory prevents it from taking flight. A flashbacks sequence can _show_ the key events leading to Travis being here as he is and feeling the way that he does. Alternatively, the "fill that in later" path, would be to just play the funeral scene straight, have Travis choose to go for a walk instead of to return, and then use the walk as a way to establish. Maybe he sees some "first route" kinds of pokemon and laments that he couldn't even catch one of those when he did manage to get some balls. He could see someone with a quality starter and rue that his parents never agreed to a vacation trip that would include a stop at a Lab. And as he goes deeper into the wild and higher up the hill he could start to realize the danger he's put himself into and _then_ contemplate if even having a starter he might be as unprepared as he is right now. Stuff like that gives lots of opportunity for building tension while establishing backstory while the main story doesn't break stride.

>>52913832
I get what you mean with the pacing, I should really try to stop writing giant chunks of introspection like that. However one thing I can't compromise is the trip into the wilderness being incidental. It's very important that it was a conscious choice, since when I came up with the idea for the story, one of the main themes was to be complacency, and with that, a recurring thematic development of someone wanting to do a thing and then just doing it. I was explicitly trying to fit that kind of development twice into the first chapter just to establish it as strongly as possible, because I had planned to use it for future arcs and other characters, applying it in different ways and so on. That's part of why I was hesitant to open with a big flashback, because it doesn't let me establish the thematics I want quite as strongly out of the gate. I could go way heavier on the complacency, to be sure, but ultimately that would end up not hitting the tone I wanted for this first chapter

In any case, all that introspection is definitely due to get cut up and spaced out to make way for more actual things happening

"... And this is Master Florian. Everyone, please get along with him!"

After being introduced to my homeroom class, I quickly darted my eyes to find a place to sit. Nemona eagerly waved me over, sitting in the back corner of the room. Kind of weird, since I thought she'd be interesting in learning more about Pokemon considering her love of battling. I smiled at her and sat next to her in the back, looking forward with a rush of excitement as class began.

A few minutes in, I heard a weird noise. I looked over, seeing Nemona was making a clicking noise with a mechanical pencil to get my attention. When she saw me, she winked at me and moved her hand--my eyes traveled to follow it. She had unbuttoned one small part of her white school shirt and pulled it forward to show me the inside; I could see one of her boobs. She quickly refastened it and smirked at me.

What annoys me more Fugg's story is that his version of the Pokemon world is annoying "perfect" in some ways. Sure, there are mention of stuff like conflict and the fact that there are viable Hoenn shattering threats in the form of Team Aqua and Magma, but I can't help but get the feeling that world of humans never went through the same struggles and tribulations as the "real" world, or at least does not pay enough credit to just how much had to be done for any of us to get to this point. I know that's mostly down to the source material and the like, but I can't just shake that feeling of annoyance. Same with regards to the stuff like with "no evil Pokemon" shtick. Again, source material, but what the hell is a good Pokemon without something evil to contrast it?

At least some of the later chapters are showing signs that not all is sunshine and daisies, aside from the obvious stuff. Just have to wait and see how the rest of it pans out before passing judgment.

posts.sub: What if the Muslims kept the Paldea Region?
posts.com:
What if the Muslims kept the Paldea Region?

Throughout the Medieval Era, Arceurian kingdoms warred against Muslim states after the Islamic conquests. In the era called the Reconquista, new states formed, new dynasties rose, and this fight over a peninsula fundamentally changed the world forever.

The only way to truly know how impactful it was, is to take it away. What if the Reconquista had failed? No Paldea. No East Province Paldea. Its a long journey ahead.
